comments.commentBody: Linda, I am grateful this Thanksgiving for your keen eye, open heart and vividness of expression.  I always appreciate your comments, which add much to our discussions on nytimes.com.  I am grateful for our staunch online community here.

I am thankful that I not only know how to read, but that I do read. I grew up solidly middle class in segregated Texas yet I always felt a need to help the poor and to see people in ways that weren't very common in the segregated south. I can't help but think that it came from my reading. I'm still horrified when the ghost of Christmas present opens his robe to show that Ignorance and Want are the things to fear most. Last night I finished reading Winter's Bone. Real humans are the monsters in this book. Maybe we turn to fantasy vampires and zombies because it's too hard to look at the monsters in our lives. I'd think Winter's Bone was make believe except that I see the same lifestyle here in this small Oklahoma town everyday.
Charles Dickens turned his society around and made people see the curse of poverty, child labor, ignorance and want. He did this through his writing. If people don't read, and they live in their gated communities and don't know any body who is different than they are, then they have isolated themselves from a great number of their fellow humans. Do they even see them as their fellow humans?
As the good businessman, Jacob Marley said when it was too late to lose his chains and money boxes, "Mankind was my business!"

And just who decides what is "decisions and good conduct" ?

It's a good decision if you live in a jobless ghetto, to join a gang and become a criminal, because at least you'll eat, and have some semblance of protection...

To stand upon the hill and decide "that is a bad choice", when there aren't any others for the people who made those choices, is exactly the lack of compassion being decried by Nick.

Many conservatives want to shut off the government tap completely (and expect the less fortunate among us to rely exclusively on personal responsibility) while many liberals simply want more money spent on more government programs with no corresponding demand for personal responsibility.  Neither extreme is likely going to work and neither extreme (including the liberal extreme) is truly compassionate. The middle ground is to provide a substantial social safety-net but to insist that recipients take a significant portion of responsibility for their own decisions (and reap a significant portion of the consequences, good and bad, for their decisions and conduct).

Beautifully written article brings back the nostalgia from the Radio days.  In this fast paced internet society, we forget the slow paced periods when the information exchange was slow, and radio did play a key role in mass media.  This article flashed back the memories from the era of radio, b&w television, vibrant color television (still improving), internet, emails, and fast moving social networks.  How ironic is it that when a new technology takes over, we look on the past technologies with dismay.  But are we not losing something in return - the peace and solace.  We ask ourselves - are we really improving lives? Having seen it all, I am not so sure if Tanzania is really at a disadvantage!

If this were carried out to the extreme, the Blue Codes that exist in most states should be enforced: NO BUSINESS SHOULD BE OPEN SUNDAY OR ANY RELIGIOUS HOLIDAY.

Let's play this game both ways. Businesses cannot have it both ways.

"when churches were taxing the citizens to pay for their upkeep, even from those who were not members of that or an religion."

They are still doing that. It is called a "tax exemption."

@Josh Thomas

As I recall from reading the biography of James Madison, the primary reason for the Freedom of Religion clause, was because certain religions were state religions, and were supported by taxes.

As i recall there was a term "antidisestablishmentarianism."

Antidisestablishmentarianism is a political position that originated in 19th-century Britain in opposition to proposals for the disestablishment of the Church of England, that is, to remove the Anglican Church's status as the state church of England, Ireland, and Wales. ...

You cite on colony, but the others were not so fortunate. Rhode island was the first colony that did not have a state religion.

Am I anti religion, well it serves a purpose, but it is still based on superstition and ignorance. But ignorance seems to to be a valid point of view these days.

If the court were to rule in favor of Hobby Lobby,what would prevent a Jehovah's Witness owned business from refusing to pay for a blood transfusion?

Could a Jewish owned business require that employees could not bring food in their lunch bags that is not kosher. What is to prevent any public company from deciding what laws it likes, and what does not like?

Since when is religion above the right of the public in general. Could a Jewish owned company require all employees wear a yarmulke in their buildings?
The First Amendment is protect the public from religion, as much as it is to allow religion to be practiced by its own followers, but it was written when churches were taxing the citizens to pay for their upkeep, even from those who were not members of that or an religion.

I personally resent the "Under God" in the pledge, and frequently say "Under Zeus, or under Wotan" which raises ire in many that hear it. Of course I do it just to tweak them anyway.

You practice your religion in your church, your home, but you leave the public out of it. when the AF sent me to Massachusetts in the 1950s, I was just amazed at the religious oriented laws. Bakeries could not sell after 24:00 Saturday. It even proscribed what sexual positions a married couple could engage in, and condoms were illegal to use.

And they thought we still lived in Teepees here and carried out six guns out here in Lala land. It was a mysterious exotic place to them.

Certainly no shopping. Unreflective consumerism is only doing good to China, not to the US.
Quiet dinner with the close family, no outsiders welcome. It is a family affair, not a social occasion.

Black Friday is a spectator sport for us... funny to see people standing in a long line hours before a store even opens, in all kinds of weather. Better to give gifts of your time or particular expertise than go into debt buying presents that no one really needs anyway. Does anyone even remember what they got for Christmas last year??? Bet you're still paying interest on those gifts too! Better to save your money & your sanity & shop post-holiday for the real (as opposed to contrived) sales.

I've never really bothered to do much outside shopping at all on Thanksgiving/Friday or the following weekend. Too many friends and family to reconnect with over just a few days. Movies, Concerts, Museums, Theater, and restaurant meals have almost always consumed my Holiday weekend. This year I started buying new computers and electronics early "Black Friday" offers on-line in late October.
Why bother when you can shop online at any time?

Jennifer, you might want to get the rest of the story about that study. The data was seriously misrepresented. Read this analysis of the study by Dr. Farsalinos, of the Onassis Cardiac Surgery Center, Greece, University Hospital Gathuisberg, Belgium and a researcher who has been studying ecigs since 2011: ecigarette-research.com/web/index.php/2013-04-07-09-50-07/141-south-korean. So this study, and the results of a CDC survey (http://www.forbes.com/sites/jacobsullum/2013/11/20/cdc-belatedly-reveals... debunks the premise that ecigarettes have an insidious impact on youth. The reality is that many kids will try smoking, alcohol and engage in other risky activities. If ecigs get kids away from smoking, that's a good thing.

Karen,

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/26/us/as-homeless-line-up-for-food-los-an...
Three cheers for maps!  But this one was so small I could not read it.

Thank you so much for the map! It makes the reading experience so much richer for those of us who are learning much of this for the first time.

I only wish the maps and other illustrations had an enlargement feature for those of us with elderly eyes.

@Wikobobo, my deepest thanks for my glaring error.  This proves yet again *never* read the NY Times when sleepy or groggy and while just scanning the page and / or comment section!  Lessons learned, and I just woke up from a pre-holiday nap here in N. California at 54.3 F @ 7:45 pm.  This farm and food issue is one that is sooooooooooo complex historically that I am going to leave it to to here to sort out, however the cost of land here around the SF Bay Area is so high and the demand so bizarre that most farms are located in other very rural areas of the state.  Silicon Valley *used* to be all fruit and nut orchards and the number of wineries in Sonoma and Napa county are wall to wall staggering.  It's all life and land out of any balance.  Supporting local farmers and healthy food/s in the slow food movement is one direction and destination of restoring something that maybe we only had for a very brief fleeting moment of time.  One of my women friends who returned from Cambodia this year, told me that she had lost ten lbs. and was already *very* thin.  The reason was that at one end of the spectrum the flies were all over the food that was prepared in the open markets in town and at the other end, big AG business had moved in and easily convinced the locals to turn their crops over to high yield, fast grow, ultra-chemical laden goop, all bound for global distribution.  Tragic and yet painfully familiar.  They will all have to learn the hard was as we have and are.
Would you be willing to take a lower price for what you provide to the economy if  your market/employer provided you a less than competitive price/wage?

The Chinese are planting pecans as fast as they can. US producers have a window of opportunity because pecans take at least a decade to reach production.

Pass on a week's worth of fancy coffee or flavored bottled water and spend the money on some shelled pecans. That'll help you live until the Chinese trees start to produce and US producers are struggling again.
Women will not be admitted to the priesthood until celibacy is put aside. I'm sure the current priests consider women enough of a distraction without having to deal with them in church government.

I think Rush Limbaugh has spent too much time living alone and listening to the sound of his own voice.

Does he even know how to have real conversations? Is he able to connect with other people? He seems to have real trouble with understanding what motivates humans. He hasn't had success with a long term relationship. He has no kids.

There is nothing wrong with people who are more comfortable inhabiting their own world and interacting with people via a microphone. But what's scary is that this is a person who is interpreting the outside world for other people. When he is so clearly divorced from reality.

Sometimes you just need a significant other to look you in the eye and say - don't you think you're getting a bit carried away? Clearly, he doesn't have such a person, and as a result is getting more and more irrational.

lorentjd: If that were the case, every society in the industrialized world would have the same sort of income disparities as we do.  The problem here lies largely in our system of taxation, the rules of which are written primarily by the politicians our "job creators" help to elect- now more than ever.  If the rich earned "only" 40 times as much as their staff members do as opposed to, say, 50 times as much we'd end up living in a society with some degree of humanity and social justice.  But tampering with tax subsidies and levels of taxation that allow many of our richest citizens to contribute a lower share of their income than their own secretaries do would amount to- ugh! gasp!!- "redistribution of wealth."  When the affluent work 50 times as hard as the rest of us do I'll worry about whether repairing the tax system constitutes "socialism."

Stu, correct me if I'm wrong, but I suspect the current earnings ratio for the affluent vs their staff that you meant to reference is more like 500 to 1, not 50 to 1.

lorentjd, it would be helpful if you would provide an example in which "many liberals simply want more money spent on more government programs with no corresponding demand for personal responsibility" (as you stated in your comment above this thread). I have yet to run into a liberal who advocates for simply giving money to able bodied and able minded citizens for life without providing for a means to become productive members of society. That some will take advantage and game the system is a given. But those gamers are not exclusively at the lower reaches of society's scale. There are "takers" at every level.

Ray Harper: Look, we've spent trillions of dollars on social services since the 1960s.  Yet, non-marital births have increased from a single-digit percentage of birth in 1960 to over 40% of births today.  Why, despite the massive increase in spending during that period of time has that social pathology skyrocketed?  We've eliminated any stigma or consequences for that behavior (and some will even claim that that behavior is "okay").  You cannot decouple spending money from expectations about personal behavior or else the money spent will have little effect but to make poor decisions easier to make and live with.

The worship of money and hatred of the poor are essential parts of how capitalism works. Apparently, there can be no other way. Of course, this is nonsense, a lie told with increasing desperation, louder and louder, generation after generation. I am tired of billionaires and their war on the poor to sustain their narcissism. It never made any sense.There is such a thing as society and no decent reason for 400 people to have more wealth than 150 million fellow citizens, no reason for this starvation and hopelessness. As Pope Francis pithily observed, money should serve people, and we were not created to serve money.
You wash, I'll dry.  So glad to have you around the table, Ted.
You fit right in, Ted, and add a lot at the same time. Very happy to have you here.

Now that it is officially Thanksgiving (at least for those in the eastern time zone, I would like to thank everyone on WP for welcoming me so nicely into your midst. This is my first Thanksgiving here, but I hope, not my last.

I am tempted to give some individual nods to those who are particularly welcoming of newcomers- but then I realize that there are simply too many. In any event, I could never match Laszlo's feat of orchestral recognition.

Thank you all, and have a wonderful, safe and delicious holiday.

That is absurd as an absolute statement.  My grandmother was born in a one-room house with a dirt floor on the prairies of North Dakota, which made her much poorer that 99% of American poor today.   She also graduated with a college degree in 1916 (before women could even vote).  A lack of money does not incapacitate a person's brain.
Let's not forget that it's now proven that poverty overwhelms cognition and makes proper decision-making almost impossible. It's like blaming someone who was born with one leg.

I work for a website devoted to the underground performers of San Francisco and we have been covering the gentrification of the Polk Street area of the City.
Here is the link: http://underthegoldengate.com/s74

incorrect.  if you drive up from san jose to SF you'll notice there are quite a number of families here, and not all of us are wealthy.  in my family's case, our annual gross income is less than $140K/year (2 parents, 2 kids). while money is very tight and we can't even think of saving for retirement, we're very happy to be here.  we bought our unremodelled 2-bedroom 1-bath fixer in 1999, so our mortgage is much less than the rents for luxury apts described in this article.  we love being able to walk to golden gate park, the ocean, the local vietnamese pho place.  living here isn't easy (for all the reasons others describe), but for some of us, it's worth it.

wow, this is sad.  what part of town do you live in?  where do your kids go to school?  i've lived here for 25 years - since long before our kids were born - and i have yet to visit a cafe that's a "cavern made of reclaimed boards," or attend a party "filled with well-put-together, bleached-teeth tech folks sizing up each other's CVs and stock options."  there's a whole family-friendly community here in SF that it seems you haven't connected with.
Brilliant Linda.
Even if it's just Costco?

Hawk New England,

"Some of these people have certain religious views, that you are asking them to ignore, because you don't share the same beliefs."

I don't believe this is what Linda Greenhouse is saying or meaning. Some people in corporations believe one thing about contraception, and some people in corporations believe something quite different. Neither of their beliefs should govern the health care options others have. By offering contraception, the Affordable Care law is not forcing anyone to take a contraceptive, which would be a violation of the right to choose, but it is letting real people their own decisions.

If corporations are people, and corporations have religious identity, will they soon argue that corporations have souls? Do corporations go to heaven when they die?
If you buy up corporations just to shut them down, like Bain Capital did, are you committing murder since corporations are people?
The whole idea that corporations are people (with religious identity) has gotten ridiculous. And if I get to heaven and find there are big box stores there, I'm leaving.

I think this administration is the most transparent ever.  I really do.  I saw through them right away, and now it seems mostly everyone also is starting to see through them.  How much more transparent can you get?

The ones preying upon smokers and now e-cig smokers are the corporations growing rich by selling an addictive product - nicotine.  Now those corporations want to be applauded for selling their addictive product in an allegedly less poisonous format.  I am not buying their latest sales pitch.
